documentAdd.body:
My latest article in TODAY

Overseas voting: deeper, broader
To keep S'porean diaspora involved and active, more needs to be done
Wayne Soon
THE next General Election (GE) would have many firsts, such as the largest number of voters in the post-65 generation and the introduction of overseas voting.
.
With an increasing number of Singaporeans in that generation going abroad to work, study or take sabbaticals, the latter is a timely move.
.
Granting citizens abroad the opportunity to vote can only be regarded as a positive step to keeping them involved and active in matters affecting their country. Still, one wonders if more could be done for future elections, if this aim is to be fully realised.
.
Recently, the election department announced that more than 500 overseas Singaporeans would be registered to vote in the next GE â€” that's a small percentage.
.
Currently, only eight embassies or consulate generals are designated as voting centres in five countries. A Singaporean living in San Francisco would have to fly eight hours to Washington DC to vote at the Singapore embassy there.
.
Similarly, a young Singaporean who studies in Murdoch University in Perth would have to fly more than four hours to Canberra to cast his ballot at the Singapore Embassy.
.
In short, the average overseas Singaporean would find it inconvenient to vote, as many reside far from the designed voting areas. If this situation persists, many overseas Singaporeans may not even bother to register ahead of future elections.
.
It is vital that Singapore, being only a small nation, be able to extend overseas voting to as many of its citizens abroad as is practically possible.
.
Yes, in numerical terms, the Singaporean diaspora is minuscule compared to, say, the number of Filipinos or South Koreans abroad. But there is an argument, nevertheless, for investing the resources into rolling out future opportunities to vote from abroad.
.
There are two noteworthy trends.
.
The first is the complex evolution of Singapore's economy which has resulted in more people working overseas. The second is the increasing number of students overseas, as Singapore's standard of living improves and the multiplying number of scholarships opens up more opportunities.
.
So, while we have taken the first, significant step of opening up the ballot to our citizens overseas, we also need to take the next â€” of making overseas voting as accessible as possible.
.
Singapore's consulate-generals, which are in areas such as San Francisco, Osaka, Xiamen and Chicago, where many Singaporeans reside, could also be designated overseas voting centres.
.
Other places where many Singaporeans reside, including Perth, should also have appointed ballot centres.
.
If overseas voting proves viable, it could also be extended to other places where many Singaporeans reside, such as Continental Europe, Taiwan and Canada.
.
Security and logistical costs are considerable, but that should not be made the excuse for not forging ahead, given that voting is a fundamental right under the Singapore constitution.
.
An alternative to opening up consulate- generals is to introduce postal ballots for overseas Singaporeans. Instead of the long time period allowed for overseas postal balloting for other nations, Singapore could limit it to the campaigning period.
.
For example, postal ballots would be sent to overseas Singaporeans only when official campaigning starts in Singapore. If the campaign is short, like at the last GE, Singapore voters would have to send their postal ballots to the nearest embassy through express and secure mail.
.
If the mail is found to have been tampered with, the election official at the embassy would have the discretion to deny the ballot count.
.
Yes, there are potential problems of secrecy and fraud. Again, it is a matter of investing more resources to make sure there are no fraudulent overseas ballots.
.
Yet another alternative to consider for the future is Internet voting. States such as Washington and California have undertaken their own research and concluded that it is feasible if security problems can be minimised.
.
It is rather ironic to see my roommates, a Sri Lankan and South Korean, vote in their general elections through postal ballots despite both nations having a smaller GDP per capita as well as arguably more security concerns than Singapore.
.
It also amazes me how much they know about the different candidates up for elections and how passionately they feel for their home country despite being in America.
.
Should it not be time that Singapore broadens and deepens overseas voting as an institution?
..
The writer is a Singaporean studying at Carleton College in Minnesota.
